info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 11 at 10:52AM EST until January 12 at 9:15AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Carolina... South Fork Catawba River At Lowell affecting Gaston County. .A potent storm system produced 2.5-4.5 inches of rainfall across the South Fork Catawba watershed from Tuesday morning through Tuesday evening. This rainfall quickly overwhelmed saturated soils and resulted in excessive runoff and significant stream rises across southeastern Burke County, Catawba County, Lincoln County, and Gaston County, with several small tributaries of the SF Catawba River exceeding bankfull and causing Minor to Moderate flooding of adjacent areas. Inundation effects will continue to recede over the next 24 hours. Tributaries feeding the SF Catawba River have been stubbornly rising through the early nighttime hours in response to impressive soil saturation and runoff. This has prolonged the rise downstream along the SF Catawba River from Lowell to Cramerton, resulting in an increase in the expected crest from 13.6 feet to near 14.2 feet. However, most tributaries are finally cresting and receding. Therefore, the floodwave is approaching the lower reaches of the SF Catawba River and a crest is imminent, expected between midnight and 2am tonight. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...South Fork Catawba River at Lowell. * WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Moderate Flood Stage. The South Fork Catawba River may begin inundating the lowest floors and/or crawl spaces of homes along Riverside Dr. between 4th St. and 5th St. in Cramerton. Impacts may be similar to those associated with flooding on October 9th, 2005. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:15 AM EST Thursday the stage was 12.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 9.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:15 AM EST Thursday was 15.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this evening and continue falling to 3.9 feet Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.7 feet on 10/07/1949. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued by Friday morning at 900 AM EST.
